Ok, thanks a lot. I had read about 'overlays' but I also did forget about i=
t.

Bertrand

--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@.=
..> wrote:
>
> bertrand.dechoux wrote:
> > Hi,
> > 
> > I was just looking =
at Processor and wondering about the use of KeyedProperties in H3. As the c=
onfiguration is now done through a spring application context, a PropertyOv=
errideConfigurer can be used to override almost everything. So is there is =
a reason for the keyedProperties?
> > 
> > I may be missing something.
> 
>=
 KeyedProperties implements what we now call 'overlays' (to avoid 
> confus=
ion with Spring's various 'overrides').
> 
> It allows the value of a setti=
ng to vary based on the context -- usually 
>   triggered off the URI-in-pr=
ogress and current thread -- in which it is 
> checked.
> 
> For example, i=
t allows the frontier 'minDelayMs' to be the default for 
> most URIs, but =
then for some subset of URIs, usually defined by a SURT 
> prefix, assume s=
ome other value.
> 
> These alternate overlay values are collected in 'Shee=
t' beans, and 
> associated with certain SURT-prefixes or other rulesets vi=
a 
> 'SheetAssociation' beans. (You would only need to consider 
> KeyedPro=
perties yourself if implementing your own components that want 
> to offer =
'overlayable' settings.)
> 
> See this part of the H3 User Guide for more d=
etails:
> 
> https://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/Sheets
> 
> =
- Gordon @ IA
> 
> 
> 
> > 
> > Bertrand
> >
